It was as if they had a stand in writer and director for the last 10 minutes. Seriously, WTF? Who killed them and why??? What's the point in all that build up for everyone to die and we don't find out anything? 
And what's the truck at the end for- at least dispose of the dead body and flashing car, other dead bodies, and then show someone going to view the house. End Scene. This made no sense, and not in the way that makes you wonder and think. 
It was LAZY.

This just sucks. Why did the stair break? Why is there stuff piled in the labyrinth basement? No reason. When was this house built? There are no lights in the basement? And why doesn't anyone ever turn a light on when exploring a room? Whatever. Turns out, I don't care and none of it matters. Netflix should be ashamed of itself. I hope the didn't pay more than $10 for the rights to this "movie" and they should demand a refund. I know I would if I could.
A waste of time. Really. So disappointing, I've expected more of this Netflix original. The trailer is the best part.
We should've read the reviews before we started watching the movie. It started out pretty good, we thought, but toward the end the movie got screwed up. Total waste of time if you'd ask us.

This is one of the worst movies Ive ever seen on netflix. I was angry that netflix even promoted this movie as their top movie on the landing page.Several times during the first half you ask yourself how stupid the storyline is, when there is a lonely house, you dont see the house of a neighbour, then there is this guy who wants to look around in the house and nobody of know if hes still there or has gone yet. So just look outside and see if his car is still there, americans go nowhere without their car. This didnt sum up and after the first half I was asking myself why am I watching this stupid movie?
You ask questions like: Hey that blocked gangway in the cellar, exciting! You think you will be told later whats behind it. But nope. 
Until the end you have no idea about the killer, who he is, or what he wants. You only have a vast idea that he's some kind of sadist. Yeah than the movie is over, with a sudden idea that oh well, probably the kid is locked up by the police and blamed with all the killings, but then I saw that there are only 6,30 minutes left and you know: nope, there will be no retribution, nothing more but anger that you wasted the last almost 2 hrs with this movie. netflix, you out!

I am not normally adverse to the-thing-in-the-cellar genre and Netflix can usually be depended upon to produce decent quality output. Unfortunately, this particular piece of work greatly disappoints on both counts.The so-called plot is completely nonsensical. There are so many loose ends, you could knit yourself a jumper with them.Dylan Minette does a decent enough job as the terrified teenager given the paucity of the script but even his effort cannot excuse the gratuitous sadism contained therein.I don't blame the producers, as they have done an amazing job just getting this movie made in the first place.However, I do blame the intern at Netflix who commissioned and scheduled it. Perhaps its time for some adult supervision in the programming department.

I watched 50 % of this movie a few days ago and I must say that this movie is literally amazing. The plot is so well done. I really liked the plot, and for all the people complaining about the ending being so bad, maybe they want to make a prequel  idiots, obviously they won't give away who the murder is so the prequel will be more exciting. If you feel like watching one of the most incredible horror movies on Netflix, The Open House definetly does the job.
Not even worth a review. Just total garbage. Writers just give up mid script? We being trolled?

Never been so anxious to write a review on any movie but in all honesty I am very disappointed. There was no real storyline here, it was very poorly written, it took too long for the movie to get into action. What was the purpose of Chris's role here only for him to be killed?? I thought I was going to see Chris and the killer put up a fight. We never got to see what the killer actually looked like or the reason why he wanted to kill in the first place. I mean I get what you were trying to say about open houses and the possibilities of what can happen but at least give us a real story.

reviews.review_title: The worst movie I've ever watched...
reviews.content: I have been struggling for the past 20 minutes trying to understand what the heck I just watched. Do you know the things I could've accomplished in the hour and 34 minutes I spent watching this. And I stayed watching this?! I can't even spoil this movie for you that's how terrible the plot is. If I could give this movie 0 stars, I would because that's how much it sucked. I can deal with a crappy horror movie, but at least have an ending and a decent plot! Please, for the love of all things good, don't waste your time and energy on this. The only thing scary about this movie was how terrible it was.

reviews.review_title: Storybuilding is fine, storytelling is lacking
reviews.content: I'm going to be honest that, as someone who has seen a LOT of horror movies, this one I had my doubts about upon picking it to watch. At the start of the movie I was pleasantly surprised with the strong storybuilding. We were introduced to a family, money issues but still trying hard, son has dreams of the Olympics. Tragedy strikes. It's a good setup. I like horror/thriller movies with a baseline that guides you instead of just mindless scares. After this strong introduction however we slide right into 'been there done that' town and don't ever leave.I've seen movies like The Strangers and The Pact, with their 'unexpected twists'. It's a well thought out concept that's been used (succesfully) in many movies before. Plant a few people in a big-ass house that they're relatively new to and you've got yourself a paranoia dreamscape. After the family moves to the mountain house we have a few interactions with seemingly random other actors that make such brief appearances I can't even remember their faces. And I get what the writers are trying to achieve: this family is isolated and everyone around them is odd and uninviting. But for viewers that's just plain boring. There's no rational motivation behind the main character's actions.The ending, if you'd like to call it that, leaves one completely unsatisfied. Where the movie started with giving me high expectations, throughout it those expectations dropped drastically. Yet I'm still disappointed by having that slightest sliver of hope of an at least somewhat credulous explained ending destroyed.Don't watch this movie unless you're ready for a sour aftertaste.
It was such a good movie with an extraordinary plot that I didn't realize what was really happened

reviews.review_title: it is not worth to watch this!
reviews.content: At the beginning to the ending of the movie is ok but in the middle of the movie there is no clue who did to this open house since the family are moving into... the family suffers a terrible tragedy. There is no plot of why and who are doing on the purpose to this family in the open house that belongs to their family's sister. The movie is really disappointment and it is a waste of time to watch this....
'The Open House' is a complete waste of time. There isn't much else to say...

Oh boy where do I begin with this one...Questions:
1. Who or what was in the car that beeped at Logan? Why was that important? If it was the killer, why on Earth would he do that?
2. I'm still confused, was it a ghost or an actual person? This guy can move without a sound and perform impossible feats without being noticed. For example at the climax: Logan hears his mom screaming again after he leaves to go downstairs. Somehow the killer has moved his mom downstairs without Logan seeing or hearing him even though he has to carry a person with him.
3. Why was it important to the plot for the father to die? The only logical reason for the plot would be that he came back to haunt them (which ties in with my first theory of the killer being a ghost) but that makes no sense.
4. So many "manufactured tension" plot devices: the argument between Logan and his mom, Chris disappearing after going into the basement, the shady maintenance man etc......why were they important?!
5. Was the old lady even relevant to the story?
6. Why are the law enforcement in movies so goddamn stupid? "Yeah kids broke in and set a table in your dining room. They also played Silent Night to creep you out.."
......
.........
............WHY WOULD KIDS DO THAT?
7. Why was the identity of the killer a secret? Does that somehow make him scarier?
8. How tf did the killer take Chris out of the house, slit his throat, and turn on the car without Logan seeing him even though he was staring at the car the whole time?Basically, this movie left me with more questions than answers. Please don't waste your time. Whoever wrote this garbage doesn't deserve a single penny for this monstrosity. Matter of fact, neither do the actors (even though their performances we're pretty decent).

As many others have stated, this movie started off with promise for a Netflix original, which I often find hit or miss. The only reason it's getting 2 stars is because of the first half and the decent actors. Oh I was filled with naive optimism heading into the climax. Everything will make sense, I thought to myself, they'll tie it all together. I was prepared to see any of the theories I'd been developing throughout the movie come true, because they had a lot of directions they could have taken with this. But I was a fool for thinking they'd tie this up cleverly. And I won't even mention the glaring plot holes and illogical behavior by the main characters. Oh, I bet it's going to be Chris! He was a little too nice, you shouldn't just trust him and let him into your house like that! ...Ok well nope DEFINITELY not Chris... Hmmm well then it must be Martha's "not so dead husband"! And I bet she doesn't even have Alzheimer's, she just acts like she does as a cover story and she's actually in on the whole thing! Oh... well no apparently Martha does just creepily wander around the woods for NO REASON AT ALL and is going to contribute nothing to the plot but being a red herring. I guess her husband is really dead..So this killer is probably going to turn out to be the guy that ran over Logan's dad in the first place and he's been stalking them all along!......No? Are we going to get anything? No reason as to why this guy is killing? Not even a GLIMPSE AT HIS FACE AFTER DEDICATING AN HOUR AND HALF TO THIS MOVIE?!?!?! Do not waste your time on this immensely unsatisfying story. Take my word for it, there is no resolution at all. *End rant*

Netflix lost major credibility with this one. I seriously can't fathom how anyone could misconstrue that as a good movie. The acting was terrible, the plot was worse, and the ending just left me angry at everyone involved with this for wasting my time. I've literally never written a review before, but this one was so awful that it compelled me to make an IMBD account with the hopes of saving other people's time that I can't get back.

reviews.review_title: The only satisfying thing about this movie...
reviews.content:
I'm writing my first review ever, I feel unity in hate over this movie with so many others.
I've never writen any review ever, because I do think that it takes skill to write, produce and lastly sell a hot pice of trash such as this one to NETFLIX. But the crew did manage to do that so.. props for that. 
Hopefully the faliure of this movie will make them better people that will try to do better, or meth addicts that will never make another movie ever.
The only satisfying thing about this movie is that, while I have spent 90 minutes + this review + casual chit-chat about a bad movie - of my life... The camera crew, writer, director, producer, editor and actors have invested and lost so much more. 
Let that be a lesson to all of us.
It had not logic in the end. It was scary a few times but the end was just a disaster
Don't waste your time! Very disappointing. This film had potential, but fell flat

Tbh I hoped the father who "died" was actually kidnapped and was Martha's wife chained in the basement.. disappointed.... could have made such a better movie... no explanation as to why everyone wanted to go to the basement..
Must watch, super intense and there's a good plot twist.

reviews.review_title: Probably the worst movie I've ever watched.
reviews.content: The whole movie seems rushed and leaves behind more questions than answers. The acting is fine but the story is absolute garbage. You never really get to know the characters, and the things that happen never get an explanation to why they happened. All I can say is that The Open House is so bad, that you can't even laugh at how bad it is.

Whats the point of the whole made up story at the begging if nothing about that was used to provide some meaning to the end? I am amaze how no one in the production has common sense to know that if you remove the SIM card of a phone you still can call emergency that is an insult to the audience... (I dont expect that the directors have any common sense after making/writing and producing this movie)... It is a pity that Netflix promote this type of movies, is like they are underestimating the integrity and intelligence of their own subscribers...
What is the point of this movie? some sort of exercise on how to create suspense and then leave the viewer with no answers? what was netflix thinking when they bought the rights for this movie?

This film has no payoff. It serves no purpose other than to disappoint. The worst part about having watched it is knowing the hack-fraud writer/director duo are probably patting themselves on the back for producing the exact opposite of what filmmakers should strive to achieve.

This movie is so bad, it actually inspired me to write my first ever IMDB review. Maybe the problem was it being written, directed, and produced by the same two people...no one else was there to say, um, this is completely awful. I actually paused the movie to see when the climax would finally start unfolding. I was 1:14:30 in with only 16 minutes left. Then after a few deaths, the movie just literally ended. No hint about who, what, how, why, nothing. Just roll credits.
Even after reading these reviews I still gave this movie a chance. Don't be like me! Watch something else, or you will be mad at yourself at the end of the movie.
U must watch before u die. all day u will think how it ends

These Netflix originals are starting to get absurd.After several huge TV series successes I think Netflix has got drunk on this and started trolling it's customer base.This review will be the same as the others. This movie is terrible. Not in a B movie so bad that it's good, its just terrible. There are many things wrong with this movie. There is nothing believable in the outburst of the son wishing his mother died rather than the father. No angst or back story to their relationship that would make this relevant.At one point the killer sets up a candle lit dinner table with a phone, then rings it when might and son approach it. Later he climbs in to bed next to her. Only to brutally beat her tie her up break her fingers, kill her house guest then knock out the son pour water over him and leave him unconscious outside. All seems very thought out and calculated like there's a purpose. But there isn't.The movie is set up with the killers face being in the shadows, you're shown clues throughout the film, the shoes, oh look Chris has those shoes, the old lady with Alzheimer's is it her, she's creepy, is her husband really dead, why do they bring him up, why was she in their garden at night, etc etc etc you get the point it's the story of every teen horror ever, unseen person will be someone you know...It builds up at one point you think oh it's turned in to a supernatural horror, but no, the old "it's just a dream" cop out was used.After both mum and son are dead for no reason (except the son is the one to accidentally killing the mum so that at least has an answer) at all and the completely unnecessary violence toward them and the killing of Chris who was set up as the misdirect you pause the movie and see wait there is only a few minutes left how will they wrap it up, ill tell you: you just see a pick up truck driving along to see another Open House sign and the killer changes direction to drive towards it. The end.So in conclusion main characters die, for no apparent reason, no motivation, no climax, no idea by whom only to see at the end it's some nameless nutter who does this sort of thing at open houses.It almost feels like someone had a bad experience at an open house and this piece of badly written rubbish was their tantrum.Netflix has produced a few of these movies now and it seems they believe in killing off the main characters like they have watched GOT and missed the point. Needless killing and unresolved story lines work in a series not a stand alone movie.The only redeeming feature are the beautiful location.
The worst movie I have seen in a very long time. Don't waste your time watching this movie, you will be very disappointed.

I'm going to start with the positives of this movie, because despite the low rating, it does have some! Firstly, the actors are great, I cannot fault the acting at all. Secondly, I loved the scenery and the house especially, it created a creepy atmosphere. Thirdly, the entire movie up until the last 20 minutes was pretty decent.Now the bad parts...The plot. What the hell were the writers thinking? The film started out really promising and I was excited to see Netflix delve into the horror genre with its originals. The open house idea was also really creepy and pretty original. It was the ending that caused me to give this such a bad rating, who even was the killer? Why were they doing it? What the hell did it have to do with an open house? It seems to me like the writers had a decent idea and just couldn't seem to work out what the story was beyond the very basic ideas. It turns a potential 7/10 film into, for me, a 3/10 (that's pretty generous). If you want to see a semi decent film that will excite you until the last part, then go ahead. But I guarantee you will be left extremely unsatisfied.

This movie had SO much potential. It was almost like they got halfway and then rushed it, without having ANYTHING else good to add. Maybe they were trying to give the watcher an empty feeling inside after the end? Maybe the unknown is what thrill they were going after? Who knows. but this, this movie ended so terribly. Its sad to see something start so good. REDO!
Netflix seems to be pumping out Movies with no quality! This was a poor movie that could have been great had the writers put some effort into the script....Don't waste your time with this one....

This movie started off good but then it kept going. I kept wondering what was the persons reason for being in the house, and why they would not kill anyone. The killer had plenty of opportunities, while the mother and son were sleeping, when they were in the basement, but nothing happened except for the door being closed. Also, I thought that hallway in the basement might have been explored more. I was thinking that maybe when the son went in the basement looking for his mother he would have found the blockage at the end of the tunnel removed and would have found something weird or interesting, or interestingly weird. We also never got to find out who the killer was. It was strange that the neighbor was walking around when the son was trying to hide from the killer. Was she involved? Guess we'll never know. I know she didn't really fit the shape that was shown in the doorway. Matt Angel, why would you end a movie where the main people get killed and you don't even reveal the killer? If your goal was to get a bunch of 1 star reviews, congrats.

I'm not going to waste a lot of words on this , I'll just quote Ol' Neil Young.
Saw it on the tube
Bought it on the phone
Now you're home alone
It's a piece of crapOne of the worst Netflix flicks ever. Avoid at all costs.
I cannot remember watching a bigger load of crap and my memory's pretty good...

After I saw the trailer for this movie on youtube, I was actually really intrigued by it. So when I saw it previewing on the front page when I logged on to Netflix, I was excited to give it a try. It started off fairly well, I think it showed some promise and I actually wanted to keep watching to find out what happened next. It kinda gave me Get Out vibes and I was enjoying the beautiful shots of nature and the aerial views of the mountains and landscapes. Reading through the reviews here, I find that most people did not like the acting. I actually liked the acting some of the time for some of the actors. Dylan Minnette, for example, had some good scenes (SPOILER: especially when he ends up being found by the killer after a night of trying to escape through the woods) but for the most part I wasn't particularly impressed by everyone else's performances. While I haven't seen 13 Reasons Why, I hope Dylan Minnette is able to move on from this project to something much better. I admit the characters weren't very well developed and so when some of them died, I found myself more irritated than sad. Some characters seemed especially suspicious, however, they ended up not really mattering to the story whatsoever. They were just there to rack up tension. I was willing to maybe push that aside if the movie turned out to have a good plot, but alas the third act came around and where we might expect resolution and closure, we were given nothing. Nothing is ever explained, no motivations are revealed. There were certain plot points and characters that were brought out and teased but, in the end, were just left hanging. While watching the movie, I found myself theorizing, trying to pull these different loose ends together, the death of the father, the suspicious townspeople and real estate agents, anything to try to explain what and why these events were happening. The plot could have gone off in any direction, ones that would have been much more interesting than the direction it got. When I finished watching the film, I just started ranting out loud. It was really annoying as a viewer to just be given this ending.And I get it. Sometimes (SPOILERS AHEAD) bad stuff happens to good people, people in grief. Sometimes, people just get killed by people they never knew for no reason other than they were just extremely unfortunate and happened to be in the wrong place at the wrong time and easy to get to. These are things that happen in real life in the world around us all the time. And sometimes we may never find out who these killers are or what their motivations were (just as we never find out who the killer in this movie is or why he did what he did). Maybe that's what the writers were trying to do here. I don't know. All I know is that many people are mad, including myself. I have feeling that if the plot had just been better, something that could have connected some of these plot points or characters and at least given us some resolution than maybe the ending of this movie would have been acceptable. But, it just wasn't.

When I started this I thought this was a TV show!!! Im actually tripping like what even is this movie. I thought the ending was the end of the episode and I was about to click to the next episode and then it was just the end of the movie, like that is how bad the ending is. Like wtf even is this.
The movie was great until the end. Who was the killer and why was he doing this??????

reviews.review_title: Worth a watch if all you're looking for is the hair on the back of your neck to stand up
reviews.content:
If you're looking for a movie that redefines a genre, this definitely is not that. It boils down to a retelling of an old classic "the call came from inside the house" short story. Except it's not short, it's feature length. Surprisingly though, it doesn't actually feel too drawn out. Most of the scenes feel like they serve a purpose towards the payoff of the movie. The problem is that there is no payoff to the movie. The longer the movie went, the more confused I was about what the motivation of the mystery man was going to be. The main characters didn't really do anything that would make anybody mad at any point in the movie. The only thing I could think of was maybe it was a drifter living in the vacant house, and his goal was to keep the house from being sold. That wouldn't make sense though, how would messing with two random people with no intentions on buying the place accomplish that? Maybe it's the guy the mom was flirting with in the shop, and he's just a crazy perv? Turns out I put more thought into the motivations of the killer than the writers of the movie. He has no motivations, he has no mass (makes no noise the entire movie despite appearing to be well over 6 feet tall and fairly T H I C C, and wears a heavy pair of boots), and he has no face. It's a shame, the movie wasn't perfect, but the buildup was well done, the vibe was creepy and isolating, and it captured me enough to be really looking forward to the payoff. The movie was shaping up to be a well above average horror until the last 10 minutes or so.A couple side notes that I don't think are worth writing full paragraphs about, but worth mentioning:
Too much of the tension in the movie is based on the viewer preparing themselves for the obvious loud jump scares that they see coming. The plot lends itself so well to Halloween-esque eeriness that it shouldn't have had to rely so hard on loud noises.The movie's bleakness meter is off. It starts off bleak, and only gets bleaker. HUGE SPOILER: The fact that the entire happy family we saw at the beginning of the movie are dead within an hour and a half at the hands of an unnamed, unmotivated killer is pretty depressing. Not even knowing WHY the killer did it leaves us with 2 dead characters that we were attached to with absolutely no closure. I know that's how life is sometimes, but this is a movie, not life. It's supposed to have closure.Don't watch this movie if anybody you were close to died recently, mostly due to my last point. This movie is an existential tragedy disguised as a horror-thriller.To finish on a happier note, the acting in this movie was really good. All of the characters were very believable, and it felt like they were going through what they were supposed to be. At no point did a badly read line pull me out of the movie, which happens far too often with horrors.Overall, there is a lot to criticize, but enough to praise that it's worth a watch if you just want to get nervous.

Was this film created by film school dropouts? If you were directing for the first or second time would you let this pass the gate to sell just because you could or would you want to actually tell some kind of story instead of a few sentences? If I created this, I would strongly question its value on my resume of experience. Optimistic that audiences will stop supporting this kind of movie and read about what their watching as I should have before I took a chance because of my satisfaction and trust with Netflick choices for viewing. My respect for Netflicks just dropped about 5 notches and I asm ashamed of Netflicks for airing this worthless film. It just adds to the plethora of trash that no one needs to view. Disturbing links to loss of a family member do not make this a horror film and for both characters being murdered leaving the viewer without a heroine or hero to be seen anywhere leaves the story without any redeeming qualities and a waste time.

reviews.review_title: I created an account on this website for the express purpose of explaining how bad this movie is.
reviews.content:
Note, I have not marked this review as containing spoilers, as there are no elements of this movie that are worth spoiling.Now:I'm really not much of an experienced movie reviewer, but this film left me with an extraordinarily negative view of these Netflix-Original, mass-produced dollar magnets.To begin with, we are introduced to a family which is characteristic of those in the exposition of most scare films. That is to say, this particular movie is egregiously guilty of the same thing that many horror/thrillers are: a picture-perfect introduction to a happy, successful family who are riding the leeward edge of a (slightly) emotional, happy event. In this case, Logan had just run his fastest mile yet, an event that lead to conclusions of a promising future. This sugary exposition is a cheap trick to maximize the amplitude of the emotional swing that the audience feels, most likely in a bid to force the audience into an emotional contract to keep them watching. This trick has been beaten to death so violently by the movie industry that its presence is an immediate turn-off for the experienced viewer.After the introduction, the plot is force-fed down the audience's throat, leaving viewers no opportunity at all to engage in the pondering, mystery, and conjecture that makes watching a thriller so engaging.I will now list just a few of the dangling questions:
1. Who is the mysterious murderer?
2. What really happened to the neighbour's husband?
3. What is the significance of the water heater?
4. Why did the killer choose "Silent Night" as the track he set at the dinner table?
5. What was the significance of setting the dinner table?
6. What was the significance of taking Logan's contacts out, telling him to run, then strangling him the next morning? Why so much effort?
7. What is the killer's motive for the murders?
8. Why did the killer kill Logan's mother in such a complicated way?
9. At the end of the film, we see another car pull into the road up to the house, presumably to attend the open house. However, none of the guests from the open house are harmed during the movie, so what are we supposed to conclude (there is no material for conjecture here)?
10. Why was Logan's dad so deep into debt?
11. Why did the neighbour show up so often?Honestly, this movie was such a hot, steamy pile of cinematic garbage that I was obligated to create this account expressly for the purpose of this negative review. If you are reading this as a filmmaker, PLEASE do not dilute the film industry with content of such preposterously low-quality.
It's stories like this that ruin the genre. I will never watch this again. Do not watch this for the story.

I think Netflix owes us an apology for this movie! I actually thought the characters were a little more in- depth than in most horror movies. There were some truly creepy moments throughout the movie and the acting was decent. The ending, however, was terrible. I was sooo disappointed. Thought it would be more of a whodunit and why. But, nope. So pointless!!!

In the first hour nothing happens just a lot of melodrmtic acting and then in the final half hour it turns into a Hostel-like snuff film. Everybody but the killer dies and there is no point to all of this.

reviews.review_title: Spoilers Abound; What Does the End Mean?
reviews.content: Netflix originals hold a special place in my heart, so I was exceptionally disappointed with this drivel. I was taught growing up to always start criticism with a genuine compliment, so I will honor my southern upbringing with this; the actors weren't awful. In fact, if given a script that wasn't steaming garbage, maybe they could have made something passable out of it.. but no one can spin straw into gold. There were countless directions the plot could have chosen to go in but instead of tying up any loose ends it felt as though they said "screw it, lets make the ending mysterious and let everyone decide for themselves". The finished product (if I may so generously call it that) is no where near "ambiguous" and nothing short of pure laziness. For the most part the story is the trite, overdone spiel you see out of every other D-list movie: tragic death, single parent, moody teenager, creepy house, broken light switch... you get the picture. The only thing missing is the jump scene with an ominous figure walking past the doorw-- oh.. wait.. never mind. Ok ok, I'm done being a jerk. There were just so many ways to turn this around into something reasonably awesome. For example;the fixation with milk. This could have come into play with the mother/wife lamenting, "If he'd gotten the milk like i'd asked... just one more second inside the store.. the car would have missed him." or something along those lines. But no, just going to make the audience stare at milk for a while until you start to feel a little weird about it. Martha and her "dead" husband. The recently-widowed neighbor, Martha, who is supposed to be made scarier and more dangerous by the discovery of her Alzheimer's diagnosis? Her husband could have not actually died and been the killer, stalking the mother after his wife began to "leave him" mentally due to her illness, and maybe the mother reminded him of his wife in her younger years? Or perhaps he truly is dead but Martha, unable to accept this, has taken it upon herself to have the beautiful house next door that - perhaps - he had always said he wanted? Who knows. Poor Martha.the killer obviously stalked the mother. The candlelit dinner? Offing Chris, the only other competition? Picture of her late husband in the trash? So, obviously, there was some attachment to her, yet this NEVER comes up during her actual torture/murder. And why break her fingers individually? What does that do for anyone involved?the kooky real estate duo. mother and son real estate team? a veteran and a newly-licensed kid trying to gain experience? Regardless, they were two weird characters that never had any other purpose. I really had been banking on spastic and eager-to-please Ed as the killer, but how would that help them at all? Property value would plummet if it is discovered that the last tenants were gruesomely hunted and murdered, and what real estate agent would want that? So they're off the table.the dad's death would have resulted in an insurance payout, so why doesn't she have $20 for lunch? Like.. come on.maybe the sister and her husband were the killers? She has the house on the market, and the killer poured what is assumably gasoline all over an unconscious Logan and the driveway, so it did occur to me that maybe the sister and her husband were planning to burn the house to the ground for the insurance claim, then decided the two casualties would potentially result in their life insurance policies being paid to them as well? Maybe the most likely answer, in my opinion.Lastly, and probably the point that has bothered me the most, are the freaking contact lenses. Early in the movie they make a very obvious point of showing us how he takes out his contacts and - woah - everything is blurry! As earth-shattering as this is, it's made so clear that this will be a recurring theme throughout that I wasn't surprised when the villain pins him down, and carefully, gently, without causing any other harm, removes his contacts for him and then barks, "now run". Our lil athlete runs until daylight, where he collapses by a stream, only to be found (and murdered) by the same psychopath who had taken out his contacts hours before. WHY. Why would he have Logan pinned down, where he easily could have strangled him then and there and been done with it, then just to let him go? Maybe he didn't want to kill him, he just wanted to preserve his identity? THEN WHY SPEND HOURS TRACKING HIM DOWN IN A FOREST JUST TO KILL HIM THERE? We later pan over the house and see that the crime scene is left, undisturbed and exactly as we had last seen it. No clean up, no gloves worn, nothing. His fingerprints are everywhere, and I guarantee a house that ritzy has some top-of-the-line security system.This guy is going to get caught, and doesn't seem bothered by that, so why not kill the kid there, too? My ONLY guess is maybe they wanted it put a "The Most Dangerous Game" spin on it, like the killer enjoyed tracking and hunting Logan, but even that doesn't make much sense.Overall, I wouldn't waste your time on this one. But please, feel free to tell me your theories or questions!

reviews.review_title: So I'm not the only one
reviews.content: Who couldn't figure out what the f was going on and why? Really was a waste of my time. I was waiting for a big climax at the end and got nothing! I thought the dad pissed off the mob boss so he was killed and I was waiting for the mob to come get the wife and kid to pay the debt......at least that would have been something. I still don't know what the point was. Just sayin'

reviews.review_title: What the Heck Did I Just Watch
reviews.content: This dud started off slowly with no real direction. At first, I thought we were going to have a Disturbia-style movie (adoring son, with father who dies unexpectedly and tragically) and I was excited. Unfortunately, I was sorely disappointed. Mother and son know there's something creepy going on the house, but they continue to stay there. Mom says "there's no money for a hotel room". Oh well, that's that. If it were me I'd hightail it out of there and sleep in my car if I had to, but nope not these two. They go on about their business, waiting to be killed in their sleep.All along it's apparent that someone who came to the open house never actually left. When said someone finally makes an appearance, he's a nameless, faceless monster who suddenly begins violently torturing the mother. This came out of nowhere, with no purpose. The torture and killing begins and stops so abruptly it was like the writers had absolutely no place to go with it. A HUGE waste of time!

reviews.review_title: Save yourself the hassle, avoid this disappointing film altogether.

There's no explanation to the ending and you're left in the dark, wishing you'd picked something else. Why do actors take on these roles when the plot is so hopelessly bad..

reviews.review_title: A slow burning waste of time
reviews.content:
This film was rated very high on Netflix and caught my attention quickly as a horror/slasher fan. 
The story is based around a mother and son who tragically lose the boys father in a car accident (a car accident that seems intentional but is never explained).
Leaving the family in debt and unable to pay rent, the mother's sister insists they stay in her lavish second home in the middle of nowhere, that's currently unnoccupided and on the market. 
An open house is held for potential buyers to come and see the property and once everyone leaves that's when the film feels like it's about to get good! (BUT IT DOESN'T) 
Things in the house start getting messed about with, like finding a family photo in the bin and the boiler in the basement keeps making the shower run cold because someone keeps turning off, the film then becomes a home invasion movie and with not a lot to go on you start thinking who the mysterious person could be.
By this point, not a lot of people have been introduced and the 4 or so characters you do meet don't fit the person shown to be the intruder, nor does anyone seem to have any motive. 
The scares aren't very imaginative and the film soon becomes very slow and uninteresting, by this point you just want the reveal but unfortunately that never happens either. 
You finish the film on a terrible cliff hanger, wondering who?, What?, Why?
Nothing gets answered and you're left thinking "Did I miss something?" 
The film ends abruptly and you're left confused. A real shame!

I don't want to give anything away for those that want to still watch this movie but I will say it was rather good till the last 5 minutes when it seems they just decided "Hey we have some cool ways we could end this but lets just go with this crap smack in the face." Such promise to be let down in the final minutes.

reviews.review_title: Garbage - But had a chance to be GREAT
reviews.content: As most have already written, it started out well and the actors were pretty good. I really thought I was being setup for a mind-bending psychological thriller. The whole movie I thought that any minute some mind-boggling twist was going to be revealed. However, nothing happened. It was just another "killer in the house" movie that's been done so many times before. Even THAT part of it wasn't the least bit interesting or scary. I wish I had read the reviews before I wasted my time on this garbage.
Why make this movie? Was this one 90 minute excuse to shoot a finger-breaking torture scene? Because this seemed like a 90 minute excuse to shoot a finger-breaking torture scene...

reviews.review_title: The most unsatisfying movie ending I have ever witnessed.
reviews.content: The first hour or so of the movie was actually kind of good, better than most. As soon as you get to the climax of the movie however, you are left with absolutely nothing. If you are looking for a movie with a really plot this is the movie for you. If you are looking for a movie with really good dialogue, this is not the best option. And if you are looking for a movie that won't leave you wondering why you even watched it, you found absolute worst movie.Yes this movie has a good plot and the acting in it was phenominal. But the ending to the movie is summed up in 6 minutes and leaves us with nothing but a glimpse at whats next to come.

reviews.review_title: Avoid Checking In On This Open House
reviews.content: "I just wasted 90 minutes". That's all I could keep repeating to myself after finishing Netflix's new original, "The Open House". I'm going to just jump into the positives, which are very few so it won't take long. The acting of Dylan Minnette(Logan) and Piercey Dalton(Naomi) is decent, certainly the highlight of this terrible film, and I feel a sadness for both for being attached to this clunker. Also, the cinematography was very well done as well.Now that that's out of the way, I pose a question. Can an ending be SO bad that it can effectively ruin an entire movie's worth? That answer is a resounding YES. Not that this film was a masterpiece prior to the final 15 minutes, but I would say it was a decent 5-6/10 type of movie. The ending effectively dropped my personal score to a 1/10. Why you may ask? Well, because it decides to forgo the multitude of red herrings presented within the first 60 minutes(crazy Martha, weird Chris, the Dreams in the Rat House song, the dining table set-up during a "break-in") and instead goes with a nonsensical and boring ending of explaining that it turns out there just so happens to be a killer that makes his living by stalking the home-owners of open houses. I've never felt so insulted by a movie's ending like "The Open House"'s. Netflix should give anyone who watched this garbage 3 months free as compensation. If this is an indication of the direction of Netflix's original movies(Bright was also pretty bad), they should give up and just stick to their original shows.

Up until the last 30 minutes or so this is actually a decent movie. It doesn't rely on jump scares or gore and it has a good buildup. My problem with the movie is the ending and all the questions that went unanswered. It leads you to believe that there is something going on with the neighbor and her dead husband, but she serves no purpose other than to create tension and make the movie creepier. I think the trailer and the way the movie was marketed were also very misleading. I don't know if it was just me, but I thought it was going to be a supernatural thriller, the tagline "You can't lock out what's already inside" suggests that there's an evil being in the home to start with. It is also very unrealistic to suggest that a single mother wouldn't bring any kind of weapons or protection to a new home in a secluded mountain area. I mean come on not even a baseball bat or pepper spary? Overall I would say pass on this and watch another Netflix thriller.

reviews.review_title: Not the best but play on real life
reviews.content: This was not, by any means, one of the better horror films I've seen. Was it one that freaked me out though? Yes. And for a couple of reasons. So first off, this movie has a couple of false leads. The old neighbor. The friendly neighbor. A generic horror film would have you believe one of them is the killer. I was convinced for a second the loopy old lady had somthting to do with it. But no. Which is part of life, right?Then there's the matter of Logan's glasses. There's a scene in particular where you can tell you're watching from the intruder's perspective and he goes into Logan's room. They zoom to his glasses and I, a fellow super blind glasses-wearer thinks,"omg if you wanted to ruin a glasses wearing individual's life, steal their glasses." And that's what happens. For a moment anyway. The glasses are returned but that moment of misplacement, of panic, is there. And of course there are other creepy instances. Table for three and a phone anyone?But that's not the point. The point is this killer, this intruder, is someone who could be in your home now.Because we find out at the end that he isn't out to venge a debt. He has no tie to this mother and son at all. He's simply interest in unsuspecting open houses. AND ISNT THAT TERRIFYING?!So no. Not super original. Not completely thought out. But there is slight merit to it and I'm not mad I watched it.

reviews.review_title: It started out interesting but it made a sharp left into BS.
reviews.content: I rarely review movies, but after just watching it and being really pissed off I feel I should warn others to not waste their time. SPOILERS.The movie started out interesting, you get to know the characters, and then the movie presents all of these scenes that provoke question that are only vaguely to never answered. Why introduce Doris and the mystery of her dead husband, was he the killer? Why? What was his motive?They introduce the one african american in this film to only have him killed off without an evidence that he did anything to help or help the plot. Why did the killer go to all the trouble to freak them out for days and day, just kill them already and get the movie over with.I skipped through the last 25 minutes after Chris was killed because I saw it coming and was pissed that they did it. They introduce this band, and this recurring song that is supposed to have significance but it never really gets there. Was the director friends with the band and wanted to help promote them through this movie?Why did the rich sister just spring for a apartment or a room at her house in town and now to this isolated mansion-cabin. It starts out promising but then never amounts to anything but cliche and a waste of time.

reviews.review_title: Worst movie in the history of all things that have been called worst, ever
reviews.content: I have never written a movie review but this movie has inspired me to action. Never has there been a more expertly disguised pot of boiling cinematic faeces than this. I'm ashamed to say I watched the whole - I'm a hopeless optimist and so kept convincing myself that something great was about to happen. Alas, nothing even approximating good happens.The story is directionless. The overuse of sound effects is grating. The characters are shallow. The plot is non-existent. And the ending really should have gotten at least a few lead members of the production team beheaded.I wish I could report the whole thing to some type of law enforcement agency. DO NOT WATCH!

This is literally one of the WORST films I've ever seen. I'm so disappointed with this film, it had so much potential to be great, it had good actors and potentially good plots. A good horror consists in the good(victims) and the evil which I thought this film had at first before I realised with 16 minutes of the film left to watch all my questions had still not been answered, AT ALL!! 
While we thought we had the film figured out with the arrival of new characters , firstly the man that nearly got ran over, delusional Martha and her dead/ undead husband (who knows), the real estate agent, Chris the shopkeeper, and the plumber we had all come to a confused conclusion that all these people have nothing to do with slamming of doors and strange missing objects, but yet the film leads us to believe that these people are involved or know something of why the open house is so creepy but yet they know nothing. when we finally do know who the corporate is (kind of, because we still don't actually know who the man is as we don't see his face) we don't get a backstory or even a real reason as to why this psycho went through all the trouble to torture Naomi and Logan (the mom and son(main characters)) to then kill them afterwards. The film as a whole is terrible as it is full of loose ends with no actual explanation or even clues to why the events in the film happened.

I just...don't know where to start with this mess. I like Dylan Minette, so I gave it a shot, but man. Wow. Just...so much stupid in this film. So much stupid and so many red herrings that were just forced and obviously not red herrings no matter how hard they were trying to make them red herrings. They practically had neon signs flashing over them. "Hey! Look at this red herring over here! Have we made you suspicious about this character yet? Look at how suspicious they are! Totally suspicious right over here!!!" Like the neighbor. They clearly tried to make her all super creepy, but it was obvious she had Alzheimer's from her second appearance when she turned up wandering around and didn't know who the kid was. When she showed up with the banana bread and said her husband was alive they were trying to reinforce the creepy, and instead it was simply confirmation that she either had Alzheimer's or dementia before the plumber even showed up. They didn't even try to make it subtle enough for the viewer to question what was really going on. And Chris from the store. They were trying so very hard to make him seem creepy because he kept hitting on a widow and wow, look at Mister Inappropriate Advances over here, isn't he CREEPY? Except he didn't KNOW she was a widow because she never once said, "I recently lost my husband," like a normal person would to discourage the mild flirting he was attempting. And then the stuff with the house! 1) If there's no light in a basement, I'm not going down there until a light is installed. 2) I sure as hell am not going down into a basement that doesn't have a light in nothing but a towel to relight a pilot light that keeps getting clearly turned to "OFF." Maybe the first time (MAYBE, but I'm sorry, I don't know any woman, including myself, who would walk into a cobwebby, lightless basement in nothing but a towel), but after that - nope. 3) Why didn't the mother say to the plumber, "You don't understand - the pilot light doesn't keep going out, it keeps switching to 'OFF.' That's not normal, is it?" Because that just doesn't happen, and whatever coil he said he changed wouldn't have any impact on a faulty knob, and if the knob isn't faulty that means someone is turning it off. 4) WHY would you move to an isolated house in the woods that doesn't have a security system and where there are open houses being held and then once strange things start happening not go to the nearest animal shelter and get yourself a big ol' dog, at the VERY least, to protect you? 5) WHY wouldn't you tell your mother that someone clearly moved your cereal bowl right before the pilot light went out on the boiler? 6) WHY WOULD YOU GO BACK TO THE HOUSE AFTER FINDING SOMEONE HAD BEEN MESSING AROUND IN YOUR DINING ROOM??? I don't care HOW hard-up you are! I don't care if the police searched the place and didn't find anything! Someone has clearly been in this house you're staying in, weird freaking things have been happening to indicate you are not alone in the house for days, drive back to California and sleep in your flipping car if you have to!SUCH a stupid movie that should not have gone the way it did except that the two protagonists were too stupid to live. They practically deserve Darwin awards. Also, don't tell me that killer managed to silently track that kid all the way through the night in the dark without the kid hearing him. Just...SO. MUCH. STUPID.
Movie idea was good, but ending was HORRIBLE!!! I have never in my almost 59 years watched a movie where all the main visible characters died!!!!! Wish I had never watched it!
